titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Charles FitzGerald Scrapbooks, circa 1901-1918, in the Archives of American Art AAA.fitzchar
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Judy Ng
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing and digitization of this collection was provided by the Sansom Foundation.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 210348

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-02-19T10:13-0500

did.abstract: Six scrapbooks of art critic Charles FitzGerald measure 1.1 linear feet and date from circa 1901 to 1918. They are comprised of newspaper clippings from the Evening Sun, Sun, New York Times, and other newspapers. Many of the printed articles, except where noted, were written by FitzGerald. Miscellaneous letters to FitzGerald are interleaved within the books and additional loose letters, writings, newspaper clippings, and notes are found. Also included are note cards that contain an index to Scrapbooks #4-6.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Charles FitzGerald scrapbooks were donated in 1964 by Ira Glackens, FitzGerald's nephew, and in 2007 by Susan Corn Conway. Glackens was the son of portrait painter William Glackens and Edith Glackens; Edith's sister, Irene Dimock FitzGerald was married to Charles. Conway purchased the Glackens' house where additional scrapbooks were located.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: The collection was digitized in 2014 and is available on the Archives of American Art's website. Blank pages have not been scanned.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Materials received a preliminary level of arrangement at some point after donation and were partially microfilmed on reel 101. All materials were prepared for digitization and described by Judy Ng in 2014 with funding provided by the Sansom Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Charles FitzGerald scrapbooks, circa 1901-1918. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Charles FitzGerald scrapbooks are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Art critic Charles FitzGerald (1873-1958) lived and worked in New York City, New York and was known for his articles promoting Ash Can school artists. As a writer for the New York Evening Sun and the New York Sun newspapers, FitzGerald frequently published critiques of the National Academy of Design, Society of American Artists, and other conventional art and institutions of his day. In 1915, he married Irene Dimock, whom he had met eleven years prior at the wedding of his close friends, the painter William Glackens and his wife, Edith Dimock Glackens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Six scrapbooks of art critic Charles FitzGerald measure 1.1 linear feet and date from circa 1901 to 1918. They are comprised of newspaper clippings from the Evening Sun, Sun, New York Times, and other newspapers. Many of the printed articles, except where noted, were written by FitzGerald. Miscellaneous letters to FitzGerald are interleaved within the books and additional loose letters, writings, newspaper clippings, and notes are found. Also included are note cards that contain an index to Scrapbooks #4-6.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 1 series.

list.item: Series 1: Charles FitzGerald scrapbooks, circa 1901-1918 (1.1 linear feet; Boxes 1-4)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The six scrapbooks consist of clippings from the Evening Sun, Sun, New York Times, and other newspapers. Many of the articles, except where noted, were written by Fitzgerald. Topics include art, current events, education, medicine, the Navy, and war.

A handful of miscellaneous letters to Fitzgerald are interleaved within the books along with additional loose letters, writings, miscellaneous newspaper clippings on sculptures and photographic processes, and essay notes on works by old masters. Also included are cards that contain a subject index to Scrapbooks #4-6.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by document type.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: This series has been scanned in its entirety.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clippings relate to wax bust by Leonardo da Vinci.
